sub_topic: Calculating the heat of formation of a molecule
message_1: What is the heat of formation of hydrogen chloride (HCl) if the enthalpy change of the reaction 2H2(g) + Cl2(g) -> 2HCl(g) is -184.6 kJ/mol?
message_2:
The heat of formation of hydrogen chloride (HCl) can be calculated from the given enthalpy change of the reaction. The reaction is:

2H2(g) + Cl2(g) -> 2HCl(g)

The enthalpy change for this reaction is -184.6 kJ/mol. Since 2 moles of HCl are formed in the reaction, we can divide the enthalpy change by 2 to find the heat of formation for 1 mole of HCl:

Heat of formation of HCl = (-184.6 kJ/mol) / 2 = -92.3 kJ/mol

So, the heat of formation of hydrogen chloride (HCl) is -92.3 kJ/mol.
